section.name: Introduction
section.p: This document provides developers with simple documentation for getting started with Loom. For information about the overall structure of Avalon Framework (on which Loom is based), please refer to the Framework documentation.
Instructions for downloading and installing Loom can be found on the Install document.
More detailed instructions will be added to this document in the future. Feel free to send in patches ;)

section.name: View Detailed API Documentation
section.p:
To generate a full set of detailed API documentation for Avalon, go to the base directory of source distribution and run the appropriate build script for your platform with the parameter 'javadocs'.
> build.[bat|sh] javadocs

section.name: Run the HelloWorld example
section.p: After you have successfully built Loom, you can verify that it has compiled correctly by running the HelloWorld demo Service Application.
Firstly you will need to get the demo-helloworld.sar file and drop it into the apps directory of Loom. Currently it needs to be built from CVS - TODO -- demo application

Then fire up phoenix with the following command:
> bin/run.[bat|sh]

Next, fire up your favorite webbrowser and point it to http://localhost:8999/, where localhost is the network name of your machine ("localhost") should work on all windows platforms.
If all goes well, you will see something like the following:
Hello World! Requests so far = 1 you are 127.0.0.1 at 127.0.0.1
This shows that Loom has unpacked and launched the server application contained within the demo-helloworld.sar file. If you close and relaunch Loom, it should restart the application.

As examples go this is a fairly simple one. You should ignore the altrmihelloworldserver, rmihelloworldserver and soaphelloworldserver packages as they are retrofitting the helloworld demo with remote capability using three technologies. HelloWorld uses connection management from the Avalon-Cornerstone project, which is good as it allows us to share connection pooling across multiple servers.

section.name: The Loom Developer Kit - A different example
section.p: This self contained kit could be considered a starter project for someone wanting to make a Loom compatible application. The idea is that you start with this skeleton including Ant build script and then add in more and more as your se code to copy from elsewhere.

This also demonstrates that it is possible to make a server application that is dual mode. Dual mode to us is the ability for the server application to run inside Loom and to stand-alone from the command line. It is a little bit of a sleight of hand as the codebase would be zipped into two forms - the sar file for phoenix and a jar file for standalone.
The Loom development kit originates in Loom's CVS. When you have that file, unzip it and immediately launch ant to make the jars and sars. There are four:

ol.li: phoenix-demo.sar - the server app in Loom form
phoenix-demo-client.sar - a client app to test the server
phoenix-demo-server.sar - the server app in standalone form

section.p:
The Server app in standalone mode after being tested with the client app(see below):
java -jar phoenix-demo-server.jar PDK Demo listening on port 7654 Ctrl-C to exit String passed = Hello!!!!!
The Server app running inside Loom and after being tested with the client app (see below):
Loom 4.0a4
Server started on port 1234 String passed = Hello!!!!!
The client application being used to poke the server :
java -jar phoenix-demo-client.jar localhost 7654 Hello!!!!!
(Change the port to 1234 from 7654 to poke the in-Loom server).

Note - because of the need to make this dual mode, the PDK does not use Cornerstone components. We normally recommend that people should reuse components from cornerstone as the potential for sharing will be much higher.
